entry.title: How vampires became allergic to the sun
entry.summary: In the 1922 film, Nosferatu, the main character gets struck by sunlight and bursts into flames a few seconds later. This moment caused a key shift in vampire folklore, creating the concept that vampires are night creatures who are unable to exist in the sunlight. The trope of vampires burning in the sun is a 20th century invention‚Äîbut daywalkers are making a comeback.  Thanks to centuries of folklore, novels, movies, and TV shows, the tropes of vampires are carved deep into the popular imagination: The creatures drink blood, sleep in coffins, recoil from garlic and crucifixes, and are susceptible to a wooden stake through the heart. Perhaps most of all, they‚Äôre creatures of the night who can‚Äôt handle daylight. But that‚Äôs not always the case. Some vampire stories e‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why you need to see this medieval-style German tournament
entry.summary:
Ulm's fisherfolk jousting imaginatively presents the city's history through characters like the police (left) and the ‚ÄòKrettaweber‚Äô (right), the infamously bad-mouthed vegetable seller. In July, the southern German city of Ulm transforms its river into a dramatic stage where costumed jousters in boats vie for glory and try to avoid a watery plunge.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As two flat-bottomed river boats steer towards each other from either bank, powered along by a crew of three oarsmen, thousands of knuckles tense. The route is short, the boats cutting swiftly across the Danube to the sound of pounding drums. All eyes are on the two costumed men, each standing at the stern of his boat with a lance positioned on his hip.
The aim:‚Ä¶

entry.title: Take a road trip through New York‚Äôs Finger Lakes
entry.summary:
If you have the time, hike the Watkins Glen Gorge Trail to Rainbow Falls. Find otherworldly white deer, roaring waterfalls, quirky towns, fascinating Indigenous history, and four vibrant seasons in this endlessly captivating region.
While the bright lights and skyscrapers of the eponymous metropolis often come to mind when picturing New York, once you step beyond the five boroughs, the state is often overlooked for its diversity of magical scenery rivaling much bigger states out west. The Empire State, the only one in the country with both Atlantic and Great Lake coastline, also comes equipped with three majestic mountain ranges, countless enchanting verdant forests, and perhaps its most underrated treasure among its endless captivating bodies of water‚Äîthe Finger Lakes.¬†¬†
Etch‚Ä¶

entry.title: Manhattanhenge is here. How to see New York City's best sunset.
entry.summary:
Prepare for social media‚Äôs favorite sunset.¬†
On Friday and Saturday evening, July 11 and 12, the sun will line up perfectly with Manhattan‚Äôs grid, turning the city‚Äôs streets into glowing corridors of light. This rare and radiant moment, called Manhattanhenge, provides picture perfect views straight to New Jersey. New Yorkers can catch it both nights around 8:20 p.m., weather permitting.
Manhattanhenge was named by astrophysicist and National Geographic Explorer Neil deGrasse Tyson, who was inspired by Stonehenge in Wiltshire, England. As head of the American Museum of Natural History‚Äôs Hayden Planetarium, he began calculating the dates in the late 1990s. He coined the term in 2002, according to The New York Times, though there are references to ‚Äúsolar grid day‚Äù going back to the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Superpowers are real‚Äîthese people are living proof
entry.summary:
It may not be a superpower from a sci-fi show, but the Bajau people of the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia have evolved a genetic ability to use oxygen more efficiently. This makes them excellent free divers, like fisherman Dafrin Ambotang, pictured here, in the Togian Islands, Indonesia, who can dive for up to four minutes on one breath. Scientists say that through genetics or training, even mere mortals can develop superhuman powers.
Superpowers are real. Okay, maybe humans can‚Äôt leap tall buildings in a single bound like Superman or shoot energy beams from their eyes like Cyclops. But our bodies and brains hold the potential for many seemingly superhuman feats, scientists say.
Sometimes real-life superpowers arise through genetic mutations, not unlike the origin storie‚Ä¶

entry.title: French presidents come here to unwind. You can too.
entry.summary:
Since 2014, the Fort de Br√©gan√ßon has been open to the public for three-hour guided tours. Few international visitors make it to this corner of the Mediterranean, where France‚Äôs head of state has vacationed since the 1960s. From a tour of the impressive fort itself, to the surrounding villages and vineyards, here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs worth a trip.
Picture the French Riviera and F. Scott Fitzgerald-level hedonism may spring to mind: Bronzed revelers quaffing Champagne on the beach, stars strutting the red carpet at the Cannes Film Festival, super yachts cruising the Mediterranean offshore. But few international visitors frequent the idyllic stretch of coast to the west of Saint-Tropez.
Backed by hillside nature reserves blanketed in cork oak forest, this dreamy shoreline also happens to ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Europe‚Äôs wine lovers are heading to the Peloponnese
What this shipwreck teaches about the horrors of slavery
entry.summary:
"A View Of The Cape of Good Hope, Taken on the Spot, From on Board the 'Resolution,' Capt. Cooke" by English landscape painter William Hodges, 1772. For more than 200 years, the S√£o Jos√© Paquete d‚ÄôAfrica lay hidden off Cape Town‚Äôs shore. Its excavation in 2014 uncovered a tragic story of enslavement and commerce from the time of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
For three weeks, since the Portuguese S√£o Jos√© Paquete d‚ÄôAfrica lifted anchor in Mozambique, the 512 enslaved Mozambicans crammed into its hold had been living a nightmare of seasickness, dehydration, disease, and degradation. Ahead lay a harrowing four-month crossing to Maranh√£o, Brazil, followed by a lifetime of forced labor in the cane fields.
On the voyage perhaps 20 percent would die, the average mortality rate‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore the elaborate tomb of Nefertari
entry.summary: Queen Nefertari, ‚Äúbeloved of Mut,‚Äù lived during the 19th dynasty (13th century B.C.) and was a Great Royal Wife of Pharaoh Ramses II. She was most likely his favorite and the most powerful of them. Nefertari was showered with numerous honorific titles, including Great Royal Wife, Wife of God, Mother of Pharaoh, Hereditary Noblewoman, and Mistress of Upper and Lower Egypt. However, one title, She for Whom the Sun Shines, points to Ramses‚Äô special love for Nefertari. He built a magnificent tomb for her in the necropolis at the Valley of the Queens, or Ta Set Neferu (‚Äúthe place of the beauties‚Äù) as the ancient Egyptians called it. The site is south of the Valley of the Kings, and the layout is characteristic of tombs from the time of the New Kingdom. It was excavated out of the rocky mountain‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fireflies are flourishing in places you wouldn't expect
entry.summary:
For many people across the United States, summer doesn‚Äôt truly begin until the soft glow of electric yellow and green fireflies can be seen drifting through the night.
But you don‚Äôt have to travel to the deep woods or open prairie to experience these otherworldly insects. In fact, several firefly species can be found quietly blinking in the heart of some of the United States‚Äô largest cities.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the last place you would expect to see fireflies,‚Äù says Sriram Murali, an International Union for Conservation of Nature Species Survival Commission firefly specialist and National Geographic Explorer.
This summer, Murali traveled to New York City and Washington, D.C. to photograph urban fireflies as a way to show how resilient some species are in the face of one of their greatest ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists find a royal Maya tomb filled with treasures
entry.summary:
Caana, which means "sky palace" in Mayan, is the largest structure at Caracol, Belize, rises over 140 feet above the jungle. Researchers recently found a tomb under the canopy in an acropolis to the immediate right of Caana. Found in the ancient city of Caracol, the tomb contained a rare jade mask, ceramics, and jewelry often linked to the Maya ruling class.
Deep in the dense jungles of Belize, archaeologists excavating the ancient Maya city of Caracol have unearthed what they believe to be the 1,700-year-old tomb of a ruler. If confirmed, the discovery would mark the site‚Äôs earliest known royal burial, and possibly the resting place of its founding king, Te K‚Äôab Chaak.¬†
‚ÄúThis is an extremely important discovery,‚Äù says Francisco Estrada-Belli, an archaeologist at Tulane U‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here's what a solar tornado looks like
entry.summary:
From a dark sky site in Portugal's Alqueva Dark Sky Reserve, Portuguese astrophotographer Miguel Claro captured stellar views of the sun‚Äôs chromosphere‚Äîthe orange-red layer of the sun's atmosphere‚Äîover the last few years.
The sun produces energy in its core through a process called nuclear fusion. That energy travels outward to the sun‚Äôs atmosphere, producing an extremely complex and dynamic environment with a variety of special phenomena, including solar tornadoes and solar prominences.
‚ÄúPhotographing the sun is as demanding as it is incredible,‚Äù Claro says. When he looks at the sun through his equipment, he sees ‚Äúthat the sun is always featuring something new‚Äîsomething that wasn‚Äôt there the day before.‚Äù
Below is a slew of fascinating features captured from our host star.
This time-lapse, taken April 24, 2025, showcases a twister on the sun. A solar tornado is created when magnetic fields swirl a tornado-like filament of boiling plasma in the sun‚Äôs atmosphere. According to NASA‚Äôs space-based Solar Dynamics Observatory, they can rotate at speeds up to 186,000 miles per hour. (For comparison, tornadoes on Earth only reach speeds of 300 miles per hour.) Scientists estimate there are as many as 11,000 solar tornadoes above the sun‚Äôs surface at any given moment. The solar chromosphere is seen on May 10, 2024, showing the most severe geomagnetic storm of the past 20 years, which created aurora borealis phenomena across the Northern hemisphere. A large solar prominence captured on April 24, 2025. On May 10, 2024, one of the most severe solar storms in over two decades hit Earth. Solar storms happen when sudden, strong bursts of charged particles from the sun hit Earth's atmosphere. They can trigger a beautiful light show in the form of auroras and can also wreak havoc on earthly technologies like power grids and our fleet of space-based satellites.

entry.title: Booze was banned to protect women‚Äîbut it actually empowered them
entry.summary:
For women drink openly during Prohibition. The nationwide alcohol ban, enacted in 1920 to curb social ills including domestic violence, restricted drinking across the board‚Äîbut also opened new social and economic spaces for women, who had previously been excluded from saloons and the liquor trade. Prohibition aimed to curb male violence. Instead, it gave rise to female bootleggers, policy advocates, and a cultural shift toward equality.
In June 1920, The New York Times reported that William Hartman shot and killed his wife, just after returning from a night of drinking whiskey.
It‚Äôs impossible to know what led to his actions. But stories like his appeared with disturbing regularity in newspapers during the early 20th century, illustrating the very dangers that Temperance advoc‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lifesaver: Study shows vaccine campaigns cut deaths by nearly 60 per cent
entry.summary: Emergency vaccination campaigns have slashed deaths from major infectious disease outbreaks by nearly 60 per cent since 2000, according to a new study published this week.

entry.summary: Humanitarian needs in the Gaza Strip ‚Äúhave never been higher‚Äù while the ability to assist the population has ‚Äúnever been more constrained,‚Äù a senior official with the World Food Programme (WFP) said on Friday in New York.

entry.title: UN chief condemns latest Houthi attacks on Red Sea shipping
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General issued a statement on Friday condemning the latest Houthi rebel attacks on shipping in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen.

entry.title: Desperate Afghan refugees return to an unfamiliar home
entry.summary: A chaotic wave of returnees from Iran and Pakistan is straining Afghanistan‚Äôs already fragile capacity under Taliban rule and threatening broader regional stability, said the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, on Friday.

entry.title: Celebrating the potential and promise of the largest youth generation ever
entry.summary: Young people are shaping the future and demanding a world that is just, inclusive and sustainable, the UN chief said on Friday, marking¬†World Population Day.

entry.title: ‚ÄòAn unending horror story‚Äô: Gangs and human rights abuses expand in Haiti
entry.summary: Between October 2024 and June this year, Haiti has been caught in a vicious and unending cycle. First, gang violence expanded westward into the Artibonite and Centre Departments.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Malnutrition crisis deepens for Sudan‚Äôs children as war rages on
entry.summary: Sudan‚Äôs brutal civil war is pushing more children towards the brink of starvation, the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF)¬†reported on Friday, highlighting a sharp and alarming rise in severe acute malnutrition (SAM) cases across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 150,000 Rohingya flee to Bangladesh amid renewed Myanmar violence
entry.summary: Escalating conflict and targeted violence in Myanmar‚Äôs Rakhine state have forced some 150,000 Rohingya refugees to flee to Bangladesh over the past 18 months ‚Äì the largest exodus to the neighbouring country in years.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: ‚ÄòUnacceptable‚Äô choice between getting shot or getting fed
entry.summary: Following the deaths of several children¬†in an Israeli strike on Palestinians waiting in line for¬†nutritional supplements in central Gaza on Thursday, UN humanitarian officials have once again¬†condemned the killings of people at aid distribution sites in the enclave.

entry.title: 6 of the most unusual places to stay at U.S. national parks
entry.summary: Travelers can marvel at the natural wonder of Kilauea from the comfort of the Volcano House, located near the volcano's summit at Hawai‚Äôi Volcanoes National Park. A room with a view of one of the world‚Äôs most active volcanoes? A lodge that echoes The Shining? These six hotels and resorts are once-in-a-lifetime experiences. Lava eruptions, ghost towns, stargazing beds, and horror films are features of the most unusual accommodations in or near U.S. national parks. Visitors to these 63 majestic parks can choose from a variety of traditional options, including convenient motels, cozy lodges, luxurious cabins, and modern hotels. Or they can add a curious twist to their wilderness holiday by staying in one of these six distinctive properties.¬† Great Smoky Mountains Na‚Ä¶

entry.title: Our solar system has a new mysterious visitor‚Äîwhat is it?
entry.summary:
The interstellar comet, originally called A11pl3Z and now known as 3I/Atlas, was first reported by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System (Atlas) survey telescope at El Sauce Observatory in R√≠o Hurtado, Chile. Just the third-ever confirmed interstellar object has been detected in our solar system. Here's what we know. (Spoiler: It's not aliens.)
On July 1, scientists operating a planetary defense facility saw something glimmering in the shadow of Jupiter, about 420 million miles from Earth. It certainly wasn‚Äôt a near-Earth asteroid, nor was it a regular comet. Within a matter of hours, it became clear that this voyager wasn‚Äôt even from our solar system: Its orbit was too steep, its speed was too great. Astronomers quickly concluded that this was an interstellar object‚Äîa ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 169 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 28 to May 4, 2025. A total of 5,085 panelists responded out of 5,772 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans‚Äô Views on Who Influences Health Policy and Which Health Issues To Prioritize
entry.summary: About seven-in-ten Americans say insurance companies have too much health policy influence, but partisans disagree on the CDC‚Äôs role. The post Americans‚Äô Views on Who Influences Health Policy and Which Health Issues To Prioritize appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Vietnam's Mui Ne became a Southeast Asian watersports hotspot
entry.summary:
Modest waves mean the conditions are perfect for my first-ever surfing lesson. Between wobbles on the board, Tan tells me how much his town has changed. In two decades, Mui Ne has evolved from a whale-worshipping fishing town into one of Southeast Asia‚Äôs watersports capitals.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Standing on the beach in the southern Vietnamese fishing village of Mui Ne, I can‚Äôt shake the feeling that I‚Äôm being watched. Before me, the South China Sea is glistening in the late-morning sun, murmuring softly, lapping the white sand and fragmented scallop shells that lie scattered at my feet. All around me is a hive of activity. Under the shade of a ramshackle tented workshop, with colourful tarpaulins stretched across upright poles of‚Ä¶

entry.title: International Criminal Court: War crimes, systematic sexual violence ongoing in Darfur
entry.summary: Systematic rape and sexual violence are being used as weapons of war in Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) warned on Thursday, as part of a widening investigation into what its Deputy Prosecutor said are escalating atrocities against civilians in the conflict-ridden region.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: She fought for the girl the world left behind: Natalia Kanem‚Äôs UN legacy
entry.summary: When Natalia Kanem reflects on her eight-year tenure at the helm of the UN reproductive health agency, she doesn‚Äôt begin with global statistics, boardroom breakthroughs, or even memories of her visits to refugee camps.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of record civilian casualties in Ukraine
entry.summary: UN agencies on Thursday warned of devastating recent attacks across Ukraine due to Russian strikes, record civilian casualties recorded last month ‚Äì and growing deprivation facing children under fire across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNICEF deplores ‚Äòunconscionable‚Äô killing of families lining up for aid in Gaza
entry.summary: The head of the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) has voiced deep dismay over the ‚Äúunconscionable‚Äù killing of children during an aid distribution in the central Gaza Strip on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fight to end AIDS: ‚ÄòThis is not just a funding gap ‚Äì it‚Äôs a ticking time bomb‚Äô
entry.summary: Devastating funding cuts from international donors are hitting countries hardest affected by HIV ‚Äî but many are showing remarkable resilience and determination to keep progress alive.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Overlooked and underestimated: Sand and dust storms wreak havoc across borders
entry.summary: There are three Great Pyramids at Giza in Egypt - but imagine if there were 307 of the mighty edifices. And then imagine that they had dissolved into over two billion tons of sand and dust particles.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN voices concern over Greece‚Äôs suspension of asylum applications
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Thursday raised alarm over Greece‚Äôs decision to suspend the submission of asylum applications from people arriving by sea from North Africa, warning it risks breaching international law and undermining the country‚Äôs longstanding commitment to protecting those fleeing conflict and persecution.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN calls for reversal of US sanctions on Special Rapporteur Francesca Albanese
entry.summary: Top UN human rights officials have voiced serious concern over the imposition of sanctions by the United States targeting Francesca Albanese, a UN-appointed independent expert on the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Meet the man who sinks the world‚Äôs biggest ships for a living
entry.summary:
The SS United States is towed at sunset past Key West, Fla., headed to Mobile, Ala., Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025, where it will be prepared to be used as an artificial reef off Florida‚Äôs Gulf Coast. How a professional ship-sinker is about to turn a famous ocean liner into the world‚Äôs largest artificial reef
Deep in the belly of the S.S. United States, some seven decks below the first-class lobby once graced by John F. Kennedy and Elizabeth Taylor, Captain Tim Mullane stands inside one of the liner‚Äôs 120 fuel tanks and stares up at a 30-foot wall slathered in oil. Armed with a power washer and outfitted in a white Tyvek suit and rubber boots, the 54-year-old Navy veteran pulls the trigger and blasts away.
Mullane sinks ships for a living and he‚Äôs prepping the United States, one of ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can CSI tactics stop a $23 billion poaching industry?
A glowing insect hidden in Appalachia is dazzling scientists
entry.summary: Often mistaken for fireflies or even worms, Orfelia fultoni are actually the glowing larvae of a fungus gnat. Measuring just 1.5 to 2 centimeters long, these translucent creatures emit bioluminescent blue light from both ends‚Äîand are most visible during late May to early June. They‚Äôre as bright as fireflies, but far harder to find. Still, experts say it‚Äôs worth seeking a glimpse of these stunning bioluminescent glowworms. Hundreds of people have gathered on a dark mountain in Appalachia. There isn‚Äôt a flashlight shining among them. Fireflies drift overhead, but the real spectacle is closer to the ground‚Äîan embankment where, nestled in damp moss, glowworms shine like pinpricks of neon blue. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just so bright!‚Äù someone exclaims. These are Orfelia fultoni, the larval‚Ä¶

entry.title: When does old age begin? Science says later than you might think
entry.summary:
Trying to put off aging forever? It‚Äôs a popular goal: The anti-aging market, valued at $40 billion, is estimated to hit $60 billion by 2032. To stave off old age, people slather on wrinkle cream, pop supplements, and lift weights, among other interventions.
Though getting older is often portrayed as a problem to fix, it‚Äôs more modifiable than you might think. According to the latest science, there‚Äôs no clear biological tipping point marking the transition from midlife to late life, says Eric Verdin, president and CEO of the Buck Institute for Research on Aging in California.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an incredible amount of variability between different people,‚Äù says Verdin, who favors using someone‚Äôs biological age‚Äîwhich is how old your cells and tissues are‚Äîrather than their chronological age, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: This animal has a built-in taser to stun sharks
entry.summary: Researchers have documented Gulf torpedo rays (Torpedo sinuspersici) using electric shocks to deter large sharks.  Electric rays are staying out of the stomachs of sharks by shocking them‚Äîwith up to 200 volts. With powerful jaws and high levels of resistance to toxins, big-bodied sharks such as tiger sharks and great whites can eat just about anything. Sea snakes venomous enough to kill a human with one bite and stingrays armed with six-inch spines are light snacks for these apex predators of the ocean.¬† Scientists have long believed that no marine creature is safe from a large, hungry shark, but at least one group of animals has evolved an effective means of evading shark digestion: electric rays. In a study published last month in the journa‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to experience Greenland‚Äôs Inuit and Viking sheep farms
entry.summary: Most visitors rarely experience South Greenland beyond its iceberg-dotted fjords and rugged mountains. Cruise ships whisk away 90 percent of visitors after fleeting glimpses, according to Sarah Woodall, destination manager at Innovation South Greenland. But longer stays offer a unique glimpse into Greenland‚Äôs sheep-farm backpacking routes, where modern Inuit communities continue Viking farming traditions from the 10th century. Trek through Greenland sheep farms with Nat GeoGreenland tourism is trending‚Äîbut the only crowds Stephanie Vermillion found on this trek were sheep. Travelers can explore nearly 40 sheep farms, nine offering overnight stays in cozy accommodations, within the 134-square-mile UNESCO World Heritage site of Kujataa. With new flight routes and an international a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Libya: UN urges restraint as military buildup threatens renewed violence in Tripoli
entry.summary: With Libya once again teetering on the brink of violence, the United Nations has issued an urgent appeal for calm amid rising military tensions in and around the capital, Tripoli.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of deepening health crisis in Gaza amid mass casualty incidents
entry.summary: As scores of people ‚Äì including medical staff and their families ‚Äì have reportedly been killed in the past week, UN health partners in Gaza continue to provide emergency care despite very limited resources.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòVery limited time to react‚Äô: Texas flash floods expose challenges in early warning
entry.summary: The deadly flash floods in central Texas that claimed more than 100 lives over the July Fourth weekend in the United States have underscored the devastating power of this fast-onset hazard ‚Äì and the critical challenge of ensuring early warnings reach vulnerable populations, even in the dead of night.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukrainian baker rises above adversity
entry.summary: At Hanna Honcharenko‚Äôs bakery in Dnipro, eastern Ukraine, the scent of freshly baked bread represents a slice of home for many. The business, born out of hardship, is proof that with trust and support it is possible start again following the loss brought on by war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen deserves hope and dignity, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Yemen continues to face a dire humanitarian crisis, driven by acute hunger, economic collapse, and regional instability, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Marital Status Shifts in the United States
entry.summary: Life expectancy and priorities changed. People stay single longer, marry later, divorce less, and widow older. Tags: marriage

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels on the Amalfi Coast
What causes coral bleaching‚Äîand how we can stop it
entry.summary:
The transformation of a once-bustling coral reef into a white ghost land is visually striking, coral bleaching also threatens ecosystems and¬†economies¬†around the world.
As¬†global warming¬†continues, coral bleaching is becoming more of a problem worldwide with¬†84 percent¬†of the world‚Äôs reefs affected by heat stress between 2023 and 2025.
(How soaring ocean temperatures are affecting corals.)
Coral¬†reefs aren‚Äôt just marine¬†biodiversity¬†hotspots, they‚Äôre critical to human life. When reefs die, the impact ripples across food systems, local economies, and climate resilience, especially in coastal communities.
Here‚Äôs everything you need to know about bleaching, its impacts on marine life and human communities, and how we can save our reefs.¬† Watch coral bleaching happen b‚Ä¶

entry.title: How does cannabis affect the body?
entry.summary:
In recent years, 24 states and the District of Columbia¬†have legalized recreational cannabis. This changing landscape has led to a dramatic rise in marijuana consumption, with some¬†62 million Americans¬†using the drug. But legalization doesn‚Äôt mean that regular consumption is completely safe.
A growing body of evidence has documented an array of concerning marijuana health effects beyond just dry mouth and fatigue and includes both mental and physical illnesses. One study even links cannabis consumption to heart disease.
‚ÄúPeople think about Bob Marley when they think about cannabis. They think it‚Äôs natural, it‚Äôs Mother Nature, that it‚Äôs not going to do any harm,‚Äù says Marco Solmi, a psychiatrist at the University of Ottawa. Yet his review of the substance published in the BMJ foun‚Ä¶

entry.title: The centuries-old practice that's reviving Scottish cuisine
entry.summary:
Coastal foraging focuses on collecting food sources from estuaries, sand dunes, tide pools, and marshlands.  Sea spaghetti, red algae, and sea buckthorn may not be the ingredients that come to mind when you think of Scottish cuisine. A resurging trend may change that.
In 2023, chef Alain Ducasse sought out Scottish harvester and fisherman Benjamin Lalande for his sustainable seafood products from the Hebrides in Scotland. Two of his chefs visited Lalande on the Isle of Rum‚Äîone of the islands that make up the Small Isles in the Inner Hebrides‚Äîwhere they sampled one of Ducasse‚Äôs requested ingredients: wild pepper dulse.
‚ÄúThis seaweed tastes like truffles,‚Äù says Lalande. It ended up on Ducasse‚Äôs Les Ombres, the quintessential venue overlooking Paris‚Äô Eiffel Tower.¬†Now, Lalan‚Ä¶

entry.title: My night with the guerrilla balloonists of South Korea
entry.summary:
In the summer winds, South Korean activists loft huge makeshift balloons filled with subversive materials and hygiene products into North Korean airspace in hopes of reaching people living in the most shuttered society on Earth.   Inside a covert operation to bombard North Korea with pantyhose and nature films.
Do you know¬†how to run fast?‚Äù asked a man I‚Äôll call Park.
He was driving us carefully through dusk, well below the speed limit, from Seoul toward the infamous Demilitarized Zone (DMZ), the heavily mined frontier between South and North Korea. It was a warm summer evening. Park, a North Korean defector who allowed me to tag along provided he could use an assumed name, was keeping a wary eye on his rearview mirror for a police tail. The only vehicle shadowing us, tha‚Ä¶

Áù™‰∏∏ÂéüÊú¨ÊòØÂú®ËÖπËÖîË£°„ÄåÊÇ∂ËëóÈï∑Â§ß„ÄçÁöÑÔºåÁõ¥Âà∞ËÉéÂÖíÂ§ßÁ¥Ñ 7 ÂÄãÊúàÂ§ßÊôÇÔºåÊâçÊúÉÂæûËÖπËÖî„ÄåÊªë‰∏ã‰æÜ„ÄçÔºåÈÄöÈÅé‰∏ÄÊ¢ùÂÉèÈößÈÅìÁöÑËÖπËÇ°Ê∫ùÔºåÊúÄÂæåÊéâÈÄ≤Èô∞ÂõäË£°„ÄÇÈÄôÊÆµÊóÖÁ®ãÂ∞±ÂÉèÊê¨ÂÆ∂ÔºåËÆìÁù™‰∏∏Âæû„ÄåÁÜ±Èçã„ÄçÊê¨Âà∞„ÄåÂÜ∑Êàø„ÄçÔºåÊâçÊúâËæ¶Ê≥ïÈ†ÜÂà©Ë£ΩÈÄ†ÂÅ•Â∫∑ÁöÑÁ≤æÂ≠ê‚ÄîÈÄôÂÄãÈÅéÁ®ãÁ®±ÁÇ∫Á≤æÂ≠êÁôºÁîü (Spermatogenesis)„ÄÇ Áù™‰∏∏ÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÊ±∫ÂÆö‰∫ÜÂÆÉÁöÑÊ∫´Â∫¶ÁâπÊÄßÔºöÂú®Ëß£ÂâñÂ≠∏‰∏äÔºåÂÆÉÊá∏ÊéõÂú®ËÖπËÖîÂ§ñÔºå‰ΩøÂÖ∂Âπ≥ÂùáÊ∫´Â∫¶ÊØîÊ†∏ÂøÉÈ´îÊ∫´‰ΩéÁ¥Ñ 2¬∞C Ëá≥ 4¬∞C [2]„ÄÇÁõÆÂâçÁ†îÁ©∂Ë™çÁÇ∫ÔºåÂú®Á¥Ñ 34¬∞C ÁöÑÁí∞Â¢É‰∏ãÔºå‰∫∫È°ûÁöÑÁ≤æÂ≠êÁîüÊàêÊïàÁéáÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÔºåËÄåÈô∞ÂõäÊ∫´Â∫¶ÈÅéÈ´òÔºåÂ∑≤Ë¢´Ë™çÁÇ∫ÊòØÁî∑ÊÄß‰∏çÂ≠ïÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÈ¢®Èö™Âõ†Â≠ê[3, 4]„ÄÇÊõ¥ÊúâË∂£ÁöÑÊòØÔºåÁ≤æÂ≠êÂú®ÂΩ¢ÊàêÈÅéÁ®ã‰∏≠ÊúÉÁî¢Áîü‰∏çÂ∞ëÁÜ±Èáè[5]ÔºåÁù™‰∏∏‰∏ÄÊó¶ÈÅéÁÜ±Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÂè™ÂçáÈ´ò 1.5-2¬∞CÔºåÂ∞±Ë∂≥‰ª•ÊäëÂà∂Á≤æÂ≠êÁöÑÁîüÊàêËàáÊàêÁÜü[6]„ÄÇÁÇ∫‰∫ÜÊáâÂ∞çÈÄôÂÄãÊåëÊà∞Ôºå‰∫∫È´îÊºîÂåñÂá∫‰∏ÄÂ•óÈ´òÊïàÁöÑ„ÄåÂ§©ÁÑ∂ÂÜ∑Ê∞£Á≥ªÁµ±„Äç‰æÜÂπ´Âä©Áù™‰∏∏Êï£ÁÜ±ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨: ‚óè Èô∞Âõä(Scrotum): ÁöÆËñÑ„ÄÅÂØåÂê´Ë°ÄÁÆ°ËàáÊ±óËÖ∫ÔºåÂà©ÊñºÊï£ÁÜ±Ôºõ ‚óè ÊèêÁù™ËÇå(Cremaster muscle): Â¶ÇÂêå„ÄåÂçáÈôçÈõªÊ¢Ø„ÄçÔºåÊ∞£Ê∫´‰ΩéÊôÇÊúÉÂ∞áÁù™‰∏∏ÊãâËøëË∫´È´î‰øùÊöñÔºåÊ∞£Ê∫´È´òÊôÇÊîæÈ¨ÜËÆìÁù™‰∏∏ÈÅ†Èõ¢È´îÊ∫´Ôºõ ‚óè ËÇâËÜúËÇå(Dartos muscle): ÊòØÈô∞Âõä‰∏≠Á∑äË≤ºËëóÁöÆËÜöÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ±§ËñÑÁöÑÁö∫Ë§∂Á≠ãËÜúËÇåÔºåÊéßÂà∂Èô∞ÂõäÁöÆËÜöÁö∫Á∏ÆÊàñÊîæÈ¨ÜÔºåÂÜ∑ÊôÇÁö∫Á∏Æ‰øùÊöñÔºåÁÜ±ÊôÇÂπ≥Êªë‰ª•Â¢ûÂä†Êï£ÁÜ±Èù¢Á©çÔºåÊúâÈªûÂÉèÈñãÈóú‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our¬†international survey methodology and country-specific [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the¬†2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey¬†(CHES), Norris‚Äô¬†Global Party Survey¬†and¬†The PopuList. We define a party as populist when at least two of these [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline
entry.summary: The post Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Who do people think is their country‚Äôs greatest threat?
entry.summary: China, Russia and the U.S. are widely viewed as top threats around the world. The U.S. is mostly seen as an economic threat, while Russia is primarily considered a security threat. The post 2. Who do people think is their country‚Äôs greatest threat?¬† appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Who do people think is their country‚Äôs most important ally?
entry.summary: People around the world often name the U.S. as their top ally. China is also a common response, while Europeans commonly name the EU or other regional powers. The post 1. Who do people think is their country‚Äôs most important ally? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: People in Many Countries Consider the U.S. an Important Ally; Others See It as a Top Threat
entry.summary: People in 12 of 24 nations surveyed tend to say the U.S. is their top ally. But it's also widely seen as a top threat, as are Russia and China. The post People in Many Countries Consider the U.S. an Important Ally; Others See It as a Top Threat appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: US tariff delay deepens trade uncertainty, warns top UN economist
entry.summary: A leading UN trade official warned on Tuesday that the United States‚Äô decision to delay the end of a tariff suspension by a few weeks risks prolonging global uncertainty and undermining long-term investments and commercial contracts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In South Asia, anaemia threatens women‚Äôs health and economic futures
entry.summary: Anaemia remains one of South Asia‚Äôs quietest but most pervasive health crises, disproportionately affecting the region‚Äôs poorest women and girls ‚Äì and with 18 million more cases projected by 2030, experts say urgent, unified action is critical.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: UN refugee agency helps repair homes amid ongoing conflict
entry.summary: As relentless attacks continue to damage homes and communities across Ukraine, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) has now helped repair over 40,000 war-damaged homes ‚Äì marking a major step in helping displaced families return and recover.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan‚Äôs longest cholera outbreak enters critical stage
entry.summary: On the eve of the fourteenth anniversary of its independence, South Sudan ‚Äì the world‚Äôs youngest country ‚Äì is experiencing its worst and longest cholera outbreak.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Hospitals rationing critical supplies, ambulances stalling
entry.summary: UN humanitarians have warned that the catastrophic conditions in Gaza are worsening, as tents, schools, homes and medical facilities come under attack, and fuel supplies run out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN summit confronts AI‚Äôs dawn of wonders and warnings
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs flagship platform on artificial intelligence opened in Geneva on Tuesday, launching four days of high-level dialogue, cutting-edge demonstrations and urgent calls for inclusive AI governance. The event comes as autonomous and generative systems evolve faster than regulatory frameworks can keep pace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Srebrenica, 30 years on: UN officials and survivors call for truth, justice and vigilance
entry.summary: At the UN General Assembly on Tuesday, survivors of the Srebrenica genocide joined top officials in marking 30 years since thousands of Bosnian Muslims were systematically killed in the worst atrocity on European soil since World War II. The affirmed the need to counter denial, support survivors and promote lasting peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office urges restraint in Kenya as fresh protests turn deadly
entry.summary: The UN human rights office, OHCHR, has expressed deep concern over the killing of at least ten protesters in Kenya on Monday, amid reports that police and security forces used lethal force to quell violent demonstrations in Nairobi and across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: On this Indonesian island, tempeh is king
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúTempeh brownies,‚Äù chef Froosh Nur announces as he places a plate down in front of me.
I‚Äôm not sure how this is going to work. I‚Äôve never tried tempeh in sweet form before, but these don‚Äôt look any different to normal brownies, and as I sink my teeth in, a familiar chocolatey taste emerges. The texture is perfectly moist and gooey; a delicate crunch comes not from nuts, but from the soybeans in the tempeh.
Originally from Kerala in Southern India, Froosh moved to the Indonesian island of Lombok last year to take up the position of head chef at The Sira, one of the many high-end resorts that line the palm-fringed turquoise coast in the island‚Äôs quieter northwest corner, between the Bali Sea and the imposing slo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Aging isn‚Äôt all bad. Here‚Äôs how health improves as we grow older.
entry.summary:
While aging is often framed negatively, researchers have uncovered surprising benefits. Above, members of a senior synchronized swimming team pose during practice. New science suggests there's plenty that actually gets better with age‚Äîif you let it.
We spend billions of dollars each year trying to fight aging‚Äîcovering up wrinkles, dyeing gray hair, and chasing the promise of youth. However, while aging is often portrayed as a slow decline, scientists say that view overlooks the bigger picture. ‚ÄúEveryone talks about aging as this decline,‚Äù says Michelle Feng, chief clinical officer at Executive Mental Health and a licensed psychologist who specializes in geriatric psychology and medicine. ‚ÄúBut aging is just living. It literally means that you‚Äôre alive.‚Äù
How you choose to think ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The 17,000th species to enter Nat Geo's Photo Ark
entry.summary:
Birds-of-paradise have captivated the planet with their elaborate plumage and idiosyncratic mating dances. Some species appear to shape-shift as they elongate plumes of feathers, fan their wings, or even hang upside down from a tree branch like a bat.
There are about 40 species in the birds-of-paradise family, and all are native to either Papua New Guinea, its surrounding islands, or Australia.
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre like no other birds on earth,‚Äù¬†says Joel Sartore,¬†National Geographic Explorer, photographer, and creator of¬†Photo Ark.¬†
Since 2006, Sartore has been traveling the globe in a bid to document as many species as humanly possible. And as of this writing, he has approached a number that once seemed unthinkable‚Äî17,000 species lovingly coaxed into posing for his camera. Usually, Sa‚Ä¶

entry.title: How mournful fado music offers a window into Lisbon's soul
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs nearing midnight in Alfama, Lisbon‚Äôs oldest neighbourhood, when a lady in black steps into a taverna.
The bar staff scurry to turn off the lights, leaving only the flickering tapers of candles to illuminate her angular features and fringed shawl, which she‚Äôs pulled tight around her shoulders. Elvira Giblott scans the room, as if reaching for a muse, then greets the two guitarists by the bar with the title of a song. In the restaurant, every fork is stilled, every wine glass untouched. She sings of Lisbon, of the beauty and struggle of life here, her voice filling the room before dropping to a velvety whisper. It‚Äôs as if her heart is breaking before our eyes.
When, several songs later, the seasoned singer‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can we diagnose Alzheimer‚Äôs earlier than we think?
entry.summary: The accumulation of neurofibrillary tangles‚Äîlike those illustrated here inside a neuron‚Äîis closely associated with cognitive decline caused by Alzheimer‚Äôs disease. A recent study found that several biomarkers implicated in Alzheimer‚Äôs are associated with cognitive decline as early as ages 24 to 44. Treating the neurodegenerative disease in its earlier stages is key to slowing cognitive decline. A new study offers hope for the future. More than a century ago, a German neuroanatomist noticed his patient acting inordinately confused. After she died, Alois Alzheimer examined her brain and discovered amyloid-beta plaques and neurofibrillary ‚Äútangles‚Ä¶

entry.title: How flash floods get so destructive so quickly
'Ash-winged dawn goddess' pterosaur just discovered
entry.summary:
Paleontologists searching the ancient rock of Petrified Forest National Park, Arizona, have uncovered an exceptional bonebed. Dating to 209 million years ago, the Triassic trove includes nearly 1,500 fossils from fish, frogs, turtles, crocodile-like predators, and more. Most remarkable of all, it yielded fossilized remains from the oldest pterosaur yet found in North America: Eotephradactylus mcintireae, or the ‚Äúash-winged dawn goddess.‚Äù
Early pterosaurs are notoriously difficult to find. The flying reptiles took to the air thanks to leathery wings of skin stretched between their bodies and an extremely elongated fourth finger. Their small size and hollow bones made flight easier but also meant their skeletons were often destroyed before fossilization could occur. The discovery of a j‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to experience Black culture in Paris
entry.summary:
Travelers searching for immersive Black or African cultural experiences in Paris can start with a stroll through March√© Dejean in the city‚Äôs La Goutte d‚ÄôOr district, also known as Little Africa. From Little Africa to the jazz cafes where Josephine Baker performed, here‚Äôs where to immerse yourself in the art, food, and culture of Paris‚Äôs African diaspora.
Creative Black minds and artisans have been present in¬†Paris‚Äôs renowned art and food scene since the 1920s. American writers like Langston Hughes and James Baldwin found a home in the city‚Äôs bustling jazz cafes, and their future works have laid the foundation for Black American literature.¬†¬†In addition to literary legends, tens of thousands of families of African origin reside in Paris, specifically in the 18th arrondissement, wher‚Ä¶

entry.title: A witch-free guide to Salem, Massachusetts
entry.summary:
Salem, Massachusetts, is renowned for its witch trials, but this charming New England town has so much more to offer. The infamous witch trials may have put this Boston suburb on the map, but they‚Äôve also overshadowed much of its magic. Here‚Äôs how to experience everything else Salem has to offer.
When 19 people were hung for witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693, they sealed the city‚Äôs identity forever as ‚Äúthe Witch City.‚Äù That‚Äôs reinforced daily by Salem itself‚Äîin the names of shops, museums, restaurants, boutiques, and school teams. Add to this neighborhoods dense with
Colonial-era homes fit for a Crucible film set, especially when the ocean fog rolls in. But nothing certifies the witch logo more than the million-plus tourists that flood Sale‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tips for Investigating Green Energy Supply Chains in the Global South
entry.summary: At an IRE conference panel, experts discussed several powerful tools and innovative techniques for uncovering harmful practices by the global alternative energy industry.

entry.title: Why the Albanian Riviera is perfect for a road trip
entry.summary:
The Albanian Riviera is about more than just sea; there are traditional villages clinging to hillsides covered by centuries-old olive groves, and ancient ruins alongside remnants of the country‚Äôs communist past.‚ÄØ Head off on a road trip along one of Albania‚Äôs most scenic stretches of coast, driving to hilltop villages and beaches that could easily stand in for the tropics.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Running down the country‚Äôs southwestern flank, from the city of Vlor√´ in the north to the village of Ksamil, the Albanian Riviera has been proclaimed the Maldives of Europe. It‚Äôs true that countless white-sand beaches dot a coastline of dazzling blue waters, from busy stretches backed by modern resorts to secluded coves. But the Riviera i‚Ä¶

entry.title: Get involved in Europe‚Äôs growing urban adventure scene
entry.summary:
Abseiling off Porto‚Äôs Lu√≠s I Bridge in Portugal is an adrenaline-filled way to see the city. Active city breaks have never been more popular, with an increasing array of creative and eye-catching options. What‚Äôs driving this trend ‚Äî and could it be good news for destinations as well as travellers?
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Packing for a city break used to involve comfortable shoes, a smart casual outfit or two, a big appetite and a sturdy liver. Indulgence was the focus, with a little light sightseeing to ward off the gout.
The contents of today‚Äôs carry-ons can look very different: swimsuits, trainers, hiking boots, waterproofs, sports kit and perhaps even a little Lycra. And that‚Äôs because, in many of our favourite European citi‚Ä¶

entry.summary: A United Nations volunteer from Japan has said as a teenager he was motivated by the ‚Äúpassion‚Äù of young people he met on an exchange programme to contribute to peace and development initiatives.

entry.title: ‚ÄòA spirit of oneness‚Äô: Cooperatives cultivating peace in South Sudan
entry.summary: Within one year, a maize and sorghum cooperative of 20 members in the Central Equatorial State of South Sudan had grown to over 150 members allowing many members to boost their income and provide for their families for the first time.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief condemns Russian strikes on Ukraine, warns of nuclear safety risk
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Saturday strongly condemned Russia‚Äôs latest wave of drone and missile attacks in Ukraine ‚Äì reportedly the largest in over three years of war ‚Äì warning that the strikes again jeopardised nuclear safety at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: These are the must-visit ancient sites of the world
entry.summary:
Visiting ancient sites, such as Machu Picchu in Peru, is an excellent way to learn about history. From the pyramids of Egypt to the jungle-choked ruins of Angkor Wat, from the magical desert capital of the Nabateans in Jordan to the everyday Roman lives revealed by Pompeii, ancient sites are among the world‚Äôs most inspiring destinations. Here are seven must-visits for your travel list.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
If you‚Äôre after must-see sights, the monuments of ancient civilisations are right at the top. And it‚Äôs not just because their temples, tombs, cities and citadels are superlative feats of archaeology ‚Äî it‚Äôs because they‚Äôre us. They reveal humanity that is different and awe-inspiring yet still relatable. You‚Äôll get the most out of ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Se√±or Snoofioso? Here's why your pet's nicknames are so weird
entry.summary:
What‚Äôs your dog‚Äôs name? Not the name listed on their vet records‚Äîbut the one that slips out when they steal a sock or tilt their head just right.
One Redditor said their pup‚Äôs name spiraled from ‚ÄúBig Stink‚Äù to ‚ÄúStinky Winky,‚Äù ‚ÄúMoo a Wink,‚Äù and eventually ‚ÄúStoop a Wink.‚Äù
These playful nicknames might seem like nonsense, but linguists say they reflect deeper patterns in how humans form bonds, express affection, and play with language. As pets have transitioned from outdoor workers to indoor companions, the way we talk to‚Äîand about‚Äîthem has also changed.
Scientific literature has shown that nicknames are a powerful way humans express affection and form connections. ‚ÄúThe nicknaming of dogs could also be viewed as a form of creative verbal play,‚Äù says Cynthia Gordon, profes‚Ä¶

entry.title: A practical guide to traveling in Vietnam
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The frenetic pace of Vietnam‚Äôs cities combined with the cultural nuances of this Southeast Asian country can be a lot for travellers to take in. Yet it‚Äôs not a difficult place to navigate ‚Äî as long as you do a bit of forward planning. Transport is visitor-friendly and plentiful, and locals are usually happy to help travellers get their bearings. Follow their lead, and you‚Äôll soon catch your stride.
Many Vietnamese people speak at least some English, particularly in big cities, but this becomes less so the further you get into the countryside. Due to past colonial influence, English and French are more widely spoken in the south than the north, but people who work in traveller-facing businesses are likely to spea‚Ä¶

entry.title: The story behind Caesar salad
entry.summary:
At Restaurante Caesar's, the Caesar salad is always made tableside, showcasing the freshness of the ingredients, and adding dramatics to the diner‚Äôs experience. Caesar salad celebrates its 101st birthday in July 2025. We look at the origins of the popular dish ‚Äî surprisingly, it doesn‚Äôt involve a certain Roman emperor.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Crisp, fresh and satisfying, Caesar salad is a dish that‚Äôs conquered dining outlets the world over, from your neighbourhood bistro and Pret A Manger to Michelin-starred marvels like Osteria Mozza in Los Angeles. While mayonnaise-heavy iterations haunt room-service menus in hotels far and wide, Caesar salad purists live and breathe its original recipe: whole romaine lettuce leaves, crunchy garlic ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What everyone gets wrong about the worst shark attack in history
entry.summary:
"The shark comes to the nearest man and that man he'd start poundin' and hollerin' and screamin' and sometimes the shark go away. Sometimes he wouldn‚Äôt go away."
Robert Shaw‚Äôs iconic monologue as shark hunter Quint in Jaws captured the horror of the day 80 years ago when sharks descended on the crew of the U.S.S. Indianapolis after the vessel was sunk by Japanese torpedoes during World War II. Thanks to the fame of the movie, that speech propelled the worst shark attack in history into public lore.
(Martha‚Äôs Vineyard locals reflect on the legacy of 'Jaws' 50 years later.)
But his speech had some critical errors. Many retellings focus on the sharks mercilessly picking off the survivors, but the terror of that day in July 1945 was ‚Äúmuch more than just a shark story,‚Äù says Lynn‚Ä¶

entry.title: This ancient city is a vegetarian traveler's dream
entry.summary:
Kutaisi, a UNESCO City of Literature, is also one of the world's oldest continuously inhabited areas. In Kutaisi, Georgia, Imeretians still forage in nature for the ingredients that compose their colorful, vegetarian-friendly fare. These restaurants and dishes are ones locals return to time and time again.
Imereti's capital still smells like the Silk Road; mid-Autumn air thickens with cheerful chatter and agreeable odors as locals nimbly navigate Kutaisi's Green Bazaar. They chomp churchkhela (strings of walnuts coated in grape-juice caramel), pivot between spice stalls armed by affable matriarchs, and accept samples from spongy wheels of Imeruli cheese.
In the background, the soft soundtrack of the Rioni River interplays with the bazaar bustle. The Caucasus Mountains, Co‚Ä¶

entry.title: This was a hotspot for great white sharks‚Äîthen they vanished
entry.summary:
Built like a torpedo with rows of terrifying 2.5-inch teeth, the world‚Äôs largest predatory shark is an intimidating sight. So intimidating that some might think an ocean without great white sharks (Carcharodon carcharias) would be a good thing. But their loss causes a ripple effect that transforms the entire ecosystem.
A new study in Frontiers in Marine Science shows what happens when sharks vanish. Seal Island, off South Africa's False Bay was once a great white hotspot‚Äîone of the few places on Earth where the sharks could be seen surging out of the water to capture prey.
‚ÄúIt was air Jaws,‚Äù says marine ecologist Neil Hammerschlag, executive director of the Shark Research Foundation Inc. and a coauthor on the new study. ‚ÄúI don't think there's anything more remarkable in nature th‚Ä¶

entry.title: The unexpected natural wonders near America's busiest airports
entry.summary:
Air travelers with an extended layover at Washington Dulles International Airport can go hiking at Great Falls Park in Virginia. Long layover? Flight delay? These nine urban hiking trails‚Äîfrom a bamboo forest to a wildlife refuge‚Äîare all within 15 miles of major U.S. airport hubs.
Flight delays at America‚Äôs major airports, once a source of anxiety, now represent opportunities for unexpected adventures. Some travelers secretly hope for a delay that provides a chance to step beyond the terminal and discover the natural wonders, such as a hiking trek through bamboo forests near¬†Atlanta¬†or a journey through a wildlife refuge in¬†Denver.
‚ÄúIn difficult moments, nature is scientifically proven to bring us peace,‚Äù said Dan Lambe, chief executive of the¬†Arbor Day Foundation. ‚ÄúResearch s‚Ä¶

entry.title: The wild is a sanctuary
entry.summary: Bend, Oregon sits at the edge of the state‚Äôs high desert, where Ponderosa pine forests meet volcanic buttes, ancient lava flows, and the vast, open spaces of the Great Basin. The elevation shifts quickly here. One moment you‚Äôre walking through sagebrush and basalt, the next you‚Äôre standing in alpine meadows beneath snow-dusted peaks. It‚Äôs a landscape of contrasts and one I keep returning to when I need to reconnect with nature, with creativity, and with stillness. Capturing the Wild with Photographer Jody MacDonaldNational Geographic photographer Jody MacDonald shares what the wild means to her: "I‚Äôve spent most of my life chasing wild, remote places. The wilderness isn‚Äôt just an escape; it‚Äôs a return to something essential. In one week, I found sanctuary in the silence of a glassy la‚Ä¶

entry.title: Shelter and safety elude Afghan women returnees from Iran and Pakistan
entry.summary: As returns of Afghan refugees and those living in refugee-like conditions from Iran and Pakistan increase ‚Äì many forcibly ‚Äì women and girls are arriving in a country where their rights, safety, and futures face severe threats, according to a new UN-led report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Human Rights Council hears grim updates on Ukraine, Gaza and global racism
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Council on Thursday heard sobering briefings on the human rights situations in Ukraine and Gaza, along with a call to confront structural racism and intersectional discrimination worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief ‚Äòappalled‚Äô by worsening Gaza crisis as civilians face displacement, aid blockades
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General is ‚Äúappalled‚Äù by the deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza, as civilians face yet another wave of mass displacement with few safe places to go.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Landless and locked out: Young farmers struggle for a future
entry.summary: Agricultural land is more than just a resource to produce food ‚Äì for many older adults around the world, a land deed is the only safety net they have as they enter their old age. As a result, they hold onto it tightly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Chile and Argentina among coldest places on Earth as polar anticyclone grips region
entry.summary: Temperatures across lower South America have plummeted ‚Äì falling as low as -15¬∞ Celsius or 5¬∞ Fahrenheit in some places ‚Äì as a rare polar cold wave grips the region, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: With sustainable development under threat, Sevilla summit rekindles hope and unity
entry.summary: The landmark Financing for Development conference in Sevilla has concluded with a renewed sense of resolve and a focus on action that can change lives worldwide, according to UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The Sevilla Commitment: A vital step to rebuild trust in global cooperation
entry.summary: Civil society organisations have welcomed the consensus reached at the landmark sustainable development conference concluding this Thursday in Seville, while cautioning that real progress will depend on sustained action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Who decides to run a marathon in their 70s? These legends
entry.summary:
Science tells us that a marathon runner‚Äôs peak performance years are between ages 25 and 35. But that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre your best years. Take it from a dozen awe-inspiring runners, all 70 and over, who we caught up with after they crossed the finish line (still flush with joy!) of this year‚Äôs Boston Marathon.
Some have been running for decades; others took it up later in life. All are in elite company: Runners over 65 made up fewer than 3 percent of all marathon participants in 2023, according to the most recent numbers from the nonprofit group Running USA. And runners over 75? Not quite .3 percent. So what keeps some of the world‚Äôs most inspiring amateur athletes committed after a whole lot of years, miles, and worn-out trainers? Good health, sure. But also clarity and camaraderie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Types of deadlines illustrated from beginning to end
entry.summary: Some deadlines come unexpected, some come staggered, and some come on a fixed‚Ä¶ Tags: deadline, Harriet Hand, illustration, Keri Facer

entry.title: This dessert sparked an international rivalry‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Sweet as it tastes, this much-loved dessert has a bitter history. As is the case with both hummus and hamburgers, the pavlova‚Äôs birthplace is hotly disputed, with Australia and New Zealand each claiming credit for the idea of crowning towers of billowing meringue with clouds of snowy cream and tumbling fruit.
Regular shots are fired back and forth across the Tasman Sea, most recently when a Kiwi energy company ‚Äòdeclared war‚Äô by installing an advert at Auckland Airport baggage reclaim stating: ‚ÄòHome is where the pavlova was really created‚Äô. Reactions on the other side of ‚Äòthe ditch‚Äô were outraged: ‚ÄòNice of them to promote tourism to Australia‚Äô was one online comment.
The feud goes all the way to the top, as the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your favorite Fourth of July foods were invented by immigrants
entry.summary:
Hamburgers are one of the main staples found at Independence Day cookouts across America‚Äîbut they actually hail from Germany. Foods like hot dogs, hamburgers, and potato salad have become menu essentials at Independence Day cookouts across the country‚Äîbut their origins actually hail from all around the world.
On a typical red-and-white checkered Fourth of July picnic table, you‚Äôll find everything from a juicy burger and a charred hot dog to piles of potato salad and seemingly endless cans of beer‚Äîit really doesn‚Äôt get more all-American.
Unsurprisingly, the foods we eat to celebrate our country's independence came to us from all over the world. In fact, none of America‚Äôs traditional cookout foods have much to do with the country‚Äôs very first birthday in 1777, a year after the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 must-do adventures in Namibia
entry.summary:
Hiking the impressive orange dunes in Sossusvlei is just one not-to-be-missed experience when visiting Namibia‚Äîand there‚Äôs so much more to see and do. Hike massive sand dunes, sleep under the stars, and enjoy world-class wildlife watching in Namibia.
Namibia is a southwestern African nation roughly twice the size of California, known for having the¬†world‚Äôs oldest desert. The Namib Desert is the scene for many of Namibia‚Äôs must-do adventures, from hiking up Sossusvlei‚Äôs distinctive red and orange dunes at sunrise to spending days exploring the Tok Tokkie Trails on foot.
Despite the harsh desert conditions, Namibia offers abundant wildlife viewing opportunities. Watch elephants, giraffes, zebras, lions, wildebeests, oryx, and other animals congregate at watering holes in‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to stay safe if you're swimming with sharks
entry.summary:
Host Bertie Gregory filming a ragged tooth shark underwater. "Sharks Up Close With Bertie Gregory" premieres on National Geographic on July 5. Although sharks aren‚Äôt the mindless man-eaters they are sometimes made out to be, experts know that staying safe involves skill, knowledge, and practice.
Slashing teeth, lifeless eyes, and a taste for human flesh‚Äîthat's what most movies might have us believe is typical shark behavior. But what is it really like to be in the water with these apex predators?
Sharks have been on Earth for longer than trees, and there are more than 500 species‚Äîfrom the infamous great white and iconic hammerhead to the gentle whale shark and pocket-sized dwarf lanternshark.
(This was the best place on Earth to see great white sharks‚Äîthen they vanished.)‚Ä¶

entry.title: What lies beneath Hitler‚Äôs war lair?
entry.summary:
The floor under Hermann G√∂ring‚Äôs residence at the Wolf‚Äôs Lair, Hitler‚Äôs secret military headquarters on the Eastern Front, revealed the human remains of five individuals, including this adult (above). While police estimate the burials pre-date WWII, others suggest they may be victims of Nazi crimes or the subsequent Soviet army. Researchers are trying to solve the mystery of human remains uncovered at the Wolf‚Äôs Lair, the Nazi headquarters turned tourist attraction.
Amateur archaeologists in Poland recently unearthed five human skeletons‚Äîeach missing hands or feet‚Äîfrom Hitler‚Äôs Wolf‚Äôs Lair, or Wolfsschanze, near the town of Kƒôtrzyn in northeast Poland.
The macabre discovery was made beneath a house once occupied by Hermann G√∂ring. The Nazi field marshal was second-in-command o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could T. rex swim? Kinda
entry.summary: Despite what's depicted in movies and books, the real Tyrannosaurus rex was likely an awkward swimmer at best.  Evidence suggests dinosaurs like tyrannosaurs were probably best suited to a version of the doggy paddle. When Michael Crichton released the novel Jurassic Park in 1990, he included a terrifying chase through one of the park‚Äôs ponds. Fictional paleontologist Alan Grant, looking after kids Lex and Tim, tries to sneak by a dozing Tyrannosaurus rex and motor across a lake away from the dinosaur. The T. rex follows, swimming after them like ‚Äúthe biggest crocodile in the world.‚Äù The scene stood out so much that it‚Äôs been revamped for the new movie Jurassic World: Rebirth. But while tyrannosaurs might swim in movies and books, could they swim in real life? ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What Norway's midnight sun season is like‚Äîin pictures
entry.summary: This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). undefined undefined To the north of Sunnfjord, the port town of √Ölesund stands out for its quiet elegance, its facades marked by art nouveau curves and carved stone details. Its centre was completely destroyed by fire in 1904 and rebuilt with great care over three years. Today, √Ölesund seems to move at its own pace. Fishing boats dock early, and the morning‚Äôs catch often ends up on a lunch plate just hours later. undefined undefined There are special properties in the fjords, too, including Union √òye, a hotel in Norway‚Äôs Sunnm√∏re Alps. Dating back to 1891, it has hosted a distinguished cast of characters, including German kaiser Wilhelm II and English author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Today, guests can enjoy a spell in the floating sauna while gazing out at the magnificent scenery of Norangsfjorden, before leaping into its cold waters. Published in the July/August 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe to¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: The wild is a playground
entry.summary:
There‚Äôs a misconception that play is frivolous. That it‚Äôs something you grow out of when you get older and life gets more serious. But in the wild, play is essential. It‚Äôs how we learn, how we adapt, how we connect with something far greater than ourselves. And for me, the wilderness has always been my playground not in the sense of ease or safety, but in the freedom it gives me to move, to test my limits, and to create without constraint.¬†
That‚Äôs exactly what brought me to the wilderness around Bend, Oregon. Capturing the Wild with Photographer Jody MacDonaldNational Geographic photographer Jody MacDonald shares what the wild means to her: "I‚Äôve spent most of my life chasing wild, remote places. The wilderness isn‚Äôt just an escape; it‚Äôs a return to something essential. In one we‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the face of an ancient Egyptian who lived 4,500 years ago
entry.summary:
This facial reconstruction of an ancient Egyptian whose genome was sequenced was based off a 3D-scan of the skull. Scientists have for the first time sequenced the most complete and oldest ancient Egyptian genome ever found‚Äîunlocking new secrets from the Old Kingdom.
  Sealed in a ceramic funerary pot, knees curled to his chin, the Egyptian skeleton lay undisturbed for thousands of years. In 1902, British archaeologists excavated him from his tomb carved into a limestone hillside in the Nuwayrat necropolis, more than 150 miles south of Cairo. While the pharaohs of his time built colossal monuments like the Great Pyramid of Giza, this man, likely a potter who lived 4,500 to 4,800 years ago, left behind a different kind of legacy: his exceptionally well-preserved DNA.¬† S‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here‚Äôs why you should visit Nashville in 2025
entry.summary:
You won't have to look far for live music on Broadway in Nashville. The Grand Ole Opry is celebrating its 100th anniversary all year‚Äîbut that‚Äôs not the only reason to visit. From hot chicken to Tennessee whiskey to Taylor Swift‚Äôs tour bus, here‚Äôs why Music City is the place to be.
Nashville is seeing a surge in tourism as a major stop in the Americana Music Triangle. Plus, with the Grand Ole Opry‚Äôs 100th anniversary, 2025 FIFA Club World Cup matches, and new flight routes from Vancouver, Orlando, Palm Beach, Indianapolis and beyond, 2025 is the year to visit Nashville.
You don‚Äôt have to be a country music fan to know (and love) the Grand Ole Opry. This iconic music venue is celebrating Opry 100 all year with special events and performances. Tour the museum during the day, an‚Ä¶

entry.title: A last glimpse inside the world‚Äôs vanishing cave societies
entry.summary:
Nearly a decade ago,¬†documentary photographer and National Geographic Explorer Tamara Merino was driving a camper van through the hot and seemingly desolate expanse of Australia‚Äôs Simpson Desert, when one of her tires blew out. The nearly 70,000 square miles of barren red dunes are not a place you want to have car trouble; summer temperatures push into the 120s, and water is scarce. Merino coaxed her van down the road and began to see signs of a town. But there was no one in sight, and the few buildings felt abandoned. Wandering the streets, she spotted a rudimentary metal cross on a hilltop. She scrambled up to take a look and found that a wide courtyard opened up below, forming the facade of an underground Orthodox church.
Merino soon discovered that she was in an opal mining ou‚Ä¶

entry.title: What are hurricanes, typhoons, and cyclones?
entry.summary:
The Louisiana town of Cameron suffered major damage and flooding during Hurricane Laura in August 2020. Coastal areas like this can be devastated by hurricane winds and storm surging. Hurricanes are getting wetter, faster, and fueled by climate change. Here's what causes them‚Äîand why they're becoming so much more destructive.
Hurricanes combine unyielding winds and torrential rain to create some of Earth‚Äôs most powerful storms. When these storms near land, wind can cause devastating damage, even spawning tornadoes. But the bigger danger is rain, which can cause catastrophic, and often deadly, flooding.
These storms gain energy from warm water and its winds whirl in a characteristic circular motion. Tropical storms are named once winds pass 39 miles per hour, and are deemed hur‚Ä¶
